awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Key 360 Species Survival Database (K3SS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase 1 project is to create a more collaborative and efficient way for scientists to combat species loss. The project proposes to create the a centralized database for a complete view of all of the issues affecting species survival which can be tracked in real-time. This project will allow scientists to expedite their research while offering the public more transparency about environmental data. The company aims to provide a high level of transparency about what factors are directly and indirectly affecting species survival and provide actionable steps that businesses, organizations, governments, and individuals can take to make a difference that they can see in real-time, and model well into the future. They seek to democratize conservation and bring new skills, people, and funding streams to the science and practice of conservation. 

This SBIR Phase 1 project consists of the development of a comprehensive database, which exists in the cloud, that encapsulates all of the factors that affect biodiversity. The project will result in a robust data system that can host and pull environmental data  from all over the world, track the populations of the world’s species, and measure conservation support and influence from the general public. The project will also allow users to query data in the cloud and use artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities to further their research. The project will track both scientific data and data about support efforts from conservation organizations and the general public. The tracking of these factors will inform decision-making bodies on what methods are most effective in preserving biodiversity. The core technical risk to be addressed through Phase I research and development is standardizing diverse qualitative and quantitative data so that they can be used together.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Godwit, a platform focused on species conservation, identified two major gaps in the market. Firstly, there is a lack of a global centralized database that stores and provides accessible data related to conservation efforts. The scattered nature of data causes delays and obstacles in decision-making for species survival. Secondly, there is no collection of data on how global support from the general population affects conservation outcomes. Without this data, scientists rely solely on direct in-field science, missing crucial information. To address these gaps, Godwit proposed building a platform during Phase 1 of their SBIR grant. The platform would allow individuals to contribute to global conservation efforts, quantify their support in a dynamic database, monitor species populations, and become a comprehensive platform for conservationists worldwide.

To ensure commercial viability and understand customer needs, Godwit participated in the Bootcamp program. Initially focused on conservation researchers, they broadened their focus based on feedback and included various stakeholders such as conservation organizations, environmental consultants, governments, and local communities. Through 36 interviews, they discovered significant unmet needs within the conservation space.

The Bootcamp research identified three key issues hindering progres delays and incomplete studies. Insufficient baseline data impacted species conservation and ecosystem protection.

During the I-Corps program, Godwit validated their hypothesis by interviewing over 100 individuals, including 37 conservation organization representatives. They focused on exploring the potential of the emerging biodiversity credit market, aligning with their platform's goals. They narrowed down their customer segment to conservation organizations and decided to focus on the intake side, supporting the development of biodiversity credits.

Godwit's research revealed significant interest from conservation organizations in tapping into the biodiversity credit space. However, many organizations felt overwhelmed and lacked guidance on entering the market. They desired a platform that removed barriers to entry and facilitated their expansion. Additionally, there was a high demand for biodiversity credits, but the supply was insufficient and there was currently not a centralized marketplace for businesses and individuals to search for and purchase credits.

Based on these findings, Godwit decided to explore the dual-sided market, with the goal to add the biodiversity credit intake tool within the platform they developed in Phase 1 alongside a marketplace for selling biodiversity credits. 

Overall, Godwit's research and development in Phases 1 of their project aimed to address the gaps in the conservation market. Their ultimate aim is continue development  to provide a platform that streamlines data collection, promotes collaboration, and facilitates access to sustainable funding through the biodiversity credit market. By fulfilling these needs, Godwit aspires to advance conservation efforts, protect species, and establish a commercially viable business.

 

 


Last Modified: 06/27/2023
Modified by: Megan Cromp

Images (1 of )
  • This image shows part of the detailed data that conservation organizations can see on individual support for their campaigns. Organizations can also see the total overall support for the year and individual campaigns.

  • This image show a preview of the campaign builder tool that allows conservation organizations to request funding, in-person volunteers, and skilled support from individuals. There are several more slides after the type of support is chosen to fill out that ultimately will create a campaign.
    Megan Cromp

    Support Options Builder
  • This image shows some of the features that are on organization�s profiles that allows them to share more information and collaborate
    Megan Cromp

    Organization Profile Features
  • The research topics feature allows conservation organizations and individuals to add the topics that they are focused on to their profiles and campaigns. Individuals can search and find organizations, campaigns, big issues, and more that are focused on that topic to collaborate and connect.
    Megan Cromp
    Copyrighted
    Megan Cromp
    Research Topics View
  • Explore the platform and find what conservation organizations are working where in the world. Find a job with filters that allow you to explore by skill, species, research topic, location, and more. These features help conservationists find the right information and individuals for their needs.
    Megan Cromp
